4921811/4894726/5185496.title: Associations of Killavullen District with the Wexford Rising of 1798
4921811/4894726/5185496.text: Major Lombard of Ballygriffin, Killarullen was killed at the battle of Oulart Hill. He belonged to the North Cork Militia at that time.Colonel Bootle of Carrigacunne Boothe, Killavullen also belonged to the North Cork Militia and according to tradition fled from Vinegar Hill and ravelled on horse-back all the way to his home in Carrigasunna.

5177600/5172290/5187760.title: Local Bravery
5177600/5172290/5187760.text: In 1798, when the North Cork Militia were in force they visited the village of Broadford and asked a brave man named Mr. Barron to give them information as to where pikes and ammunition were hidden.  He refused to inform them and to have revenge they brought him up to the chapel gate and stripped him.  Then they tied him naked to an ass car and flogged him through the village of Broadford until they brought the skin off his back.  His patriotic sister walked by his side and gave him courage not to reveal the secret or not to be looked upon as a traitor. After being flogged through the village four times he was set free and though cruelly flogged and terribly wounded lived for about a year after.  He was a grandfather of the late Edward Barron whose death occurred about fifteen years ago.

5177635/5174730/5188891.title: Local Stories
5177635/5174730/5188891.text: 323Local stories.An English regiment was stationed in Tulla in 1798.One of the soldiers (one of the ted Coats as they were called)was making his way to Ennis .A man named O Duffy was with others near Cranagher Cross .They attacked the soldier ,stripped him of his uniform ,but otherwise left him unharmed.O Duffy exchanged clothes with him ,and thus arrayed in the English uniform made his way to Wexford and fought on the side of the Irish. He fought bravely  and disting  wished himself in many battles at last dying nobly for Ireland.o Duffy was born in Maghera not far from the site of the present School.A monument to his memory can be seen in Clooney Graveyard and was unveiled by the late Re.James Kennedy  CC Quin.

5177653/5177163/5190731.title: (no title)
5177653/5177163/5190731.text: 159The yeomanry had barracks in Quin and during '98 they captured a man who refused to divulge any information to them.They had him whipped and subjected him to other cruelties.At last they decided to hang him.They procured a car and proceeded to hang him from the shafts.The shafts were not high enough to suspend the man.The Yeomanry then caused a hole to be dug  underneath the victims feet and in this way they succeeded in hanging him.This happened at the Cross of Quin.Ever since the place is haunted,and it is reported that a soldier has often been seen at the Cross.I could not discover the name of the man being hung at the Cross still lingers among the villagers.It is also a tradition that a man named Clune was tied to the shafts of a car and flogged through the village.

5177653/5177177/5190737.title: O'Duffy '98 Man
5177653/5177177/5190737.text:
173              O'Duffy '98 ManO'Duffy was born in Maghera in the house now occupied by John Murphy Maghera Cottage ,Tulla ,Co Clare. He was a member of the Society of The United Irishmen,and held high rank .he used to be drilling men in Tyredagh at night time.This did not long continue unknown to the authorities .Brown a captain of the Yeomanry in Newgrove was rather liberal in his ideas ,and told ODuffy to desist from his military activities ,as his actions were known to the powers that be. Ward's Great Grand Father owned a forge near Dundullerick Bridge in a field called Coolín na Ceardchan.  He was one Richard Hegarty and made Pikes.The Red Coats (Soldiers) were on their way from Cobh to Fermoy.  The Captain called to his forge to have his horse shod - he had a PIke [?] [?] and finished it under the coal.  This is the pike still kept by Jas. 4921909/4899949/5200835.title: Names of Fields in Rostellan Estate
4921909/4899949/5200835.text: ÁIRD  NA  SIOTHCHÁNAI live in Ballymacandrick. The distance to Rostellan from my house    is about three miles. Not far from my house there is a cross. It is called Áirdnasiothchána. A fierce battle was fought in the locality some years ago. Peace was declared at this spot.VIOLET  HILLThere is a beautiful residence occupied by a gentle-man named Jasper Smith. It is called Violet  Hill. Blue and white violets    grow there in abundance every year.CARRIGACRUMP  QUARRYThere is a quarry about a quarter of a mile from where I live and there are large caves in it. It is said there were many usefull things found in it. A golden case and croppy pikes were found there years ago. There is a river   running by the quarry. It is called Carrigacrump river.

4921777/4906310/5221813.title: Battle of Knockbrack
4921777/4906310/5221813.text:
Information from Patrick O'Sullivan, Banteer, Co. CorkAge 76.The scene of Battle of Knockbrack was pointed out to Patsy Sullivan. "Whiteboys" supposed to take part. Loc a' mharbhtha [?] near Jim Behan's Derry, across Derry Mountain, Banteer, to top of McCarthy's old farm, Knockbrack. Water always in the lake unless year is very dry.Three sharp edges to bayonets used at that time, resembling three edged file.Leather reins in British Cavalry horse until Croppy Pikes were used.Hook on Croppy Pike used to cut reins so then chains were put on bridles.Julia C. Deady, Banteer, Co. Cork.

5274069/5270899/5274116.title: Folklore - Story of '98
5274069/5270899/5274116.text: In the year '98 the testants were killed the Catholics. When they killed them they hung them on trees.A piper was passing a tree on which a dead man was hanging. He had bad shoes and he said he would exchange them for those of the dead mans.

5009282/5004403/5278649.title: Kilmuckridge District and '98
5009282/5004403/5278649.text:
Kilmuckridge District in '98Name: Anna Murphy, age 12Ballymacsimon, Kilmuckridge.The O'Briens of Tinnaberna, the O'Connors of Ballinamona, and Raymond FitzSimons of Christnaston all fought at Oulart Hill, Enniscorthy.



Name: John Hanly, age 13 years.Ballygarron, Kilmuckridge.Matthew Foley of Ballynahown fought at the Battle of Oulart Hill in 1798, he afterwards fought at Arklow where he was killed. William Bolger, Raheenaskeagh fought and fell at Oulart Hill.
